content: Establishment of National Foreign Language Coordination Council. The "National Foreign Language Coordination Act of 2007" establishes the National Foreign Language Coordination Council within the Executive Office of the President, consisting of various government officials or their designees. The National Foreign Language Coordination Council, established by the "National Foreign Language Coordination Act of 2007," includes officials such as the Secretary of the Treasury, Housing and Urban Development, Agriculture, and the Chairman of the Export-Import Bank of the United States. The Council is responsible for overseeing and implementing the National Security Language Initiative, developing a national foreign language strategy in consultation with various entities within 18 months of enactment. The National Foreign Language Coordination Council, established by the "National Foreign Language Coordination Act of 2007," includes officials responsible for overseeing the National Security Language Initiative and developing a national foreign language strategy. This strategy involves engaging with various stakeholders, conducting surveys on agency expertise and needs, and monitoring implementation through laws and regulations. Recommendations for amending title 5 of the United States Code to enhance recruitment and retention of individuals with foreign language proficiency are also included in the strategy. The National Foreign Language Coordination Council, established by the "National Foreign Language Coordination Act of 2007," focuses on recruiting and retaining individuals with foreign language proficiency for Federal employees. It also addresses the long-term goals of the National Security Language Initiative, identifies crucial priorities, evaluates Federal foreign language programs, and recommends coordination and resource allocation to maximize efficiency. Additionally, it proposes national policies and legislative actions to support promising programs at all levels. The National Security Language Initiative is a comprehensive plan to expand foreign language education for national security purposes in the United States. The Council is responsible for preparing and submitting a strategy to the President and Congress within 18 months of enactment. Meetings may be held as deemed appropriate by the Council. The Council may hold meetings as needed and must meet at least twice a year in formal session. State and local government agencies, as well as other organizations, will be invited to public meetings at least once a year. The Director has the authority to appoint necessary personnel and compensate them accordingly. Federal Government employees may be detailed to the Council upon request. The Council is responsible for developing programs to improve foreign language education, publishing newsletters, and maintaining a website with relevant information. They must also submit an annual report to the President and Congress detailing their activities and efforts to enhance language education, including any obstacles faced. The relevant committees of Congress for the National Foreign Language program include committees on Appropriations, Armed Services, Education and Labor, Oversight and Government Reform, Small Business, Foreign Affairs, and Intelligence in the House of Representatives, and committees on Appropriations, Armed Services, and Health, Education, Labor, and Pensions in the Senate. Establishment of a National Language Director appointed by the President to develop and monitor a national foreign language strategy across all sectors. The Director must have credentials and abilities in creating long-term solutions for national foreign language and cultural competency. The National Language Director, appointed by the President, will develop and monitor a national foreign language strategy. This strategy aims to establish formal relationships among major stakeholders and lead a public information campaign to raise awareness of careers requiring foreign language skills.
